author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: Andy Garcia Is the Father of the Bride in More Ways Than One
description: The actor, who’s playing the role onscreen and in reality, understands his rigid character: “He’s an amalgamation of everybody I’ve ever known, including myself.”
content: Andy Garcia still believes in the American promise of prosperity for all. “If you come here and you work hard, there’s a future for you,” he said. “There will always be obstacles, but the opportunity is there.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Four-Ingredient Peanut Butter Ice Cream, Without a Machine
description: This easy vegan treat is ready to be the star of your summer.
content: The usual path to homemade vegan ice cream is slicked with dairy-free milk — almond, coconut, cashew, hemp. But there’s another option that gives you an even richer, plusher result: oat creamer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Relief for Parents
description: Covid vaccines for young children are finally coming.
content: After months of delays, children under 5 are set to get vaccines next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Donald Pippin, Conductor on Broadway and Beyond, Dies at 95
description: As music director, he contributed to the success of acclaimed shows including “Oliver!,” “Mame,” “La Cage aux Folles” and “A Chorus Line.”
content: Donald Pippin, a versatile conductor and composer who won a Tony Award in 1963 on his first try at being musical director for a Broadway show, “Oliver!,” and went on to work on some of the biggest musicals in Broadway history, including “Mame” and “A Chorus Line,” died on June 9 in Nyack, N.Y. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Reynolds
title: How a TV Series Undersells the Danger of the Sex Pistols
description: A music critic who teaches college students about the punk movement takes stock of “Pistol,” the new FX drama about the 1970s British punk band.
content: Punk is something you can study in school these days. Students across the world earn class credit with essays examining the movement and its legacy. My niece learned about punk in the British equivalent of ninth grade. And I teach punk-related topics like DIY at California Institute of the Arts. So when I watched FX’s “Pistol,” Danny Boyle’s new limited series about the Sex Pistols, I couldn’t help looking for “teachable moments” to bring up in class next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: How Founders Decide What They Should Get Paid
description: Whether in a downturn or when things are flush, the compensation that start-up founders give themselves always sends some kind of message.
content: The first thing Karen Cahn usually says to the founder of a new start-up is, “Congratulations, that’s so great.” Then Ms. Cahn, who runs a platform that helps fund start-ups, quickly gets personal: “Do you have savings? Are you wealthy? Are you keeping your day job?” It all leads to an important but sometimes awkward question for people starting businesses now: What are you going to pay yourself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kieran Pender
title: Why Is the World’s Best Swimmer Not Swimming at the Worlds?
description: Ariarne Titmus of Australia has a perfectly good reason for missing a renewal of her rivalry with Katie Ledecky at the world championships: She didn’t feel like going.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — When the women’s 400-meter freestyle final is swum and won on Saturday at swimming’s world championships in Budapest, the reigning world and Olympic champion in the event, the race’s new world record-holder, will be halfway around the world — and fast asleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Democratic Candidates for Governor Bicker in Debate
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul faced barbs from her rivals, Representative Tom Suozzi and Jumaane Williams, the public advocate.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at last night’s fractious debate among the three candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for governor. We’ll also discover a large-scale musical work that was cut off during a long-ago radio broadcast. It will be performed tonight in anticipation of Juneteenth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Keener
title: Chess is booming
description: Chess hasn’t seen popularity like this since the 1972 World Chess Championship.
content: While many Americans were confined to their homes during the pandemic, they turned to chess to occupy their minds. A glimpse at the Google Trends history for the word “chess” shows a parabolic move in October 2020, right around the time the hit series  “The Queen’s Gambit” was released. According to Netflix, a then record 62 million households watched the series — about a troubled young woman’s journey to Chess stardom — in its first 28 days. Not since an American became world champion in 1972 had there been such a surge of interest in chess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: N.Y.C. Tried to Fix High School Admissions. Some Parents Are Furious.
description: In an attempt to democratize schools, the city is focusing less on grades, attendance and test scores. Instead, it relies heavily on a lottery.
content: Even under ordinary circumstances — ones that don’t involve a pandemic and all the learning loss and mental-health challenges that have come with it — the process of getting a child into a selective public high school in New York City is a byzantine exercise that seems to require an expertise in game theory and a time commitment roughly equal to what it takes to read “The Power Broker” several times over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: A Weird, Wild and Entirely Typical Day at the U.S. Open
description: It was a topsy-turvy second round on a vexing golf course as famed and anonymous players jockeyed up and down the leaderboard and turkeys paid a visit.
content: BROOKLINE, Mass. — M.J. Daffue of South Africa, ranked 296th in the world, was not invited to the hospitality tent alongside the par-5 14th hole during the second round of the U.S. Open on Friday. But when his tee shot came to rest on the tent’s carpeted balcony next to a tree trunk, fence railing and overhanging, leaf-filled branches, Daffue was welcomed to the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: British prime minister pays a second surprise visit to Kyiv.
description: Boris Johnson promised new military aid that would train up to 10,000 Ukrainian soldiers every 120 days.
content: LONDON — Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, on Friday paid a second, surprise, visit to the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, offering a training program for the country’s military in a fresh show of support for Ukraine’s government just a day after key European leaders made a similar trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: A Filmmaker Imagines a Japan Where the Elderly Volunteer to Die
description: The premise for Chie Hayakawa’s film, “Plan 75,” is shocking: a government push to euthanize the elderly. In a rapidly aging society, some also wonder: Is the movie prescient?
content: TOKYO — The Japanese film director Chie Hayakawa was germinating the idea for a screenplay when she decided to test out her premise on elderly friends of her mother and other acquaintances. Her question: If the government sponsored a euthanasia program for people 75 and over, would you consent to it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: For Two Foodies, ‘Love at First Bite’
description: Kung-Gene Chu knew he had found someone special in Paige Rechtman while watching her devour dumplings on their first date.
content: Rebecca Paige Rechtman made her way to Kung-Gene Chu’s heart not through his stomach, but through hers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: She Spoke Out Against Vietnam’s Plans for Coal. Then She Was Arrested.
description: The prosecution of Vietnam’s most prominent environmental activist, as well as others, has cast doubt on the country’s commitment to cut coal.
content: When the Vietnamese government decided in 2016 to cut the use of coal in its next energy plan, it followed the advice of an unusual source: one of the country’s most prominent environmentalists.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Sotomayor Says the Court Can ‘Regain’ the Public’s Confidence
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 17, 2022.
content: “Justice Thomas believes that every person can pull themselves up by their bootstraps. I believe that some people can’t get to their bootstraps without help.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Uvalde Officer Passed Up Shot at Gunman for Fear of Hitting Children
description: A police officer had a chance to shoot the gunman before he entered a school, according to a chief deputy sheriff. The officer declined to take the shot, fearing injuries to others.
content: UVALDE, Texas — A city police officer armed with an AR-15-style rifle hesitated when he had a brief chance to shoot the gunman approaching a school in Uvalde, Texas, because he did not want to hit children, according to a senior sheriff’s deputy who spoke to the officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
title: A Defiant Putin Says Russia Will Flourish Without the West
description: In a speech at an economic forum, he called the U.S. a fading power and said sanctions on Russia, not the Ukraine war, are hurting Western economies.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, seeking to rally anti-American sentiment in Europe and across the world, lashed out anew at the United States on Friday, calling it a fading power that treats its allies as colonies, and said the West was falsely blaming its economic woes on the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: W.T.O. countries agree to a limited relaxing of patent protections on coronavirus vaccines.
description: The agreement is a limited measure that is likely to have little impact on global vaccine supply.
content: The member countries of the World Trade Organization on Friday reached a limited agreement to ease intellectual property protections on coronavirus vaccines, aiming to boost the supply for poorer countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Star of Celebrated European Films, Dies at 91
description: For 50 years, in movies like “A Man and a Woman” and “My Night at Maud’s,” his specialty was playing the flawed Everyman.
content: Jean-Louis Trintignant, a leading French actor of subtle power who appeared in some of the most celebrated European films of the last 50 years, among them Bernardo Bertolucci’s “The Conformist,” Eric Rohmer’s “My Night at Maud’s” and Claude Lelouch’s “A Man and a Woman,” died on Friday at his home in southern France. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Jayson Tatum Knew He Could Have Had His Moment
description: Tatum, the 24-year-old Boston Celtics forward, learned the hard way during the N.B.A. finals just how much it takes to be a championship-level leader.
content: BOSTON — With a little more than a minute left in Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals, Celtics Coach Ime Udoka pulled his starters. That meant Jayson Tatum had a minute to sit by himself and feel the weight of disappointment that came with losing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Radiant Artists, With a Percussive Bond
description: Amanda Castro, Brinda Guha and Arielle Rosales come from different traditions but share a reverence for the dancers’ foundation: the ground.
content: If you’re familiar with the percussive dance trio Soles of Duende, the title of their latest show, “Can We Dance Here?,” answers itself long before their feet hit the stage: Yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Why Some States Are Expanding Tax-Free Periods
description: The “holidays” are aimed at helping consumers, but they’re also politically attractive. Tax experts say they provide only modest benefits.
content: This year, the back-to-school tax “holidays” that many states offer each summer are being expanded with new types of tax-free periods that are aimed at giving beleaguered consumers a break on rising prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Stolen Art: Why We Need Repatriation
description: We are honoring each of the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Serena Liu, age 15.
content: This essay, by Serena Liu, age 15, from Parkway West High School in Chesterfield, Mo., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin
title: Infighting Overshadows Big Plans at The Washington Post
description: The aim of Sally Buzbee, The Post’s editor, is to broaden the newspaper’s reach. A year into the job, she’s dealing with internal tumult over some longstanding grievances.
content: When Sally Buzbee joined The Washington Post a year ago this month, she took over a newsroom that had nearly doubled to more than 1,000 journalists under the ownership of Jeff Bezos, who bought it in 2013. Its coverage regularly won Pulitzer Prizes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Houston Is Overhauling Homelessness and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Father’s Day Can Be Hard. Here’s How to Handle the Holiday.
description: For people grieving a loss or facing thoughts “about what could have been or what may never be,” there are ways to find solace.
content: Father’s Day is complicated for Collie James. On one hand, it’s a day to celebrate with his two young sons “and get that wonderful hand-drawn card.” On the other, it’s a stark reminder that his firstborn child — Maddie, who died of brain cancer at age five in 2012 — isn’t there to sign it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: A Gull Flaps Its Wings and a Deadly Virus Explodes
description: This year’s outbreak of the H5N1 virus has resulted in the deaths of nearly 400,000 wild birds worldwide. Scientists are studying the pathways of contagion among species.
content: A great black-backed gull migrating from Europe to Eastern Canada last winter may have been the first carrier to North America of the deadly strain of avian influenza that has killed tens of millions of domestic poultry and devastated wild bird populations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Ginni Thomas Has a Lot of Explaining to Do
description: If the tables were turned, Republicans would not hesitate to use every argument and every tool at their disposal.
content: Again and again, during the years that Donald Trump was in the White House, liberals would ask themselves a single question: “Can you imagine if Barack Obama had done this?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: How to Feel Better Naked
description: Whether you want to find joy in your body, or just greater self-acceptance, these four strategies from psychologists, activists — and, yes, nudists — might help.
content: When Carolyn Hawkins went to her first nude resort four decades ago, she was 37 years old and absolutely committed to keeping her clothes on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Extradition Order for Julian Assange Approved by Britain
description: Priti Patel, Britain’s home secretary, approved the order. But Mr. Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who faces charges in the U.S. under the Espionage Act, will appeal.
content: LONDON — The British government approved an extradition order on Friday for Julian Assange, the embattled WikiLeaks founder, confirming a court decision that he can be sent to the United States to stand trial on espionage charges, though his legal fight against the decision is not over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Soccer Rediscovers the No. 9
description: The signings of Erling Haaland and Darwin Núñez were not mere summer coups for Manchester City and Liverpool. They could signal the start of a new tactical phase.
content: It took Erling Haaland a couple of seconds to notice something had changed. Late last month, Haaland, the Norwegian striker, was inside the Manchester Institute of Health and Performance, patiently and quietly going through the many and monotonous steps of the medical exam that was part of his move to Manchester City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: The Dutch intelligence service says it prevented a Russian spy from infiltrating the International Criminal Court.
description: Sergey Vladimirovich Cherkasov spent years building an identity as a Brazilian citizen, polishing a résumé that got him an internship at the court, officials say.
content: It has all the elements of an espionage thriller: An accused Russian spy who concocted an identity as a Brazilian. The creation of an elaborate cover story. And what Dutch authorities said appeared to be a foiled plot to gain access to the International Criminal Court as it investigates Russian war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: SpaceX Said to Fire Employees Involved in Letter Rebuking Elon Musk
description: In an email, Gwynne Shotwell, SpaceX’s president, said the letter had made other employees “feel uncomfortable, intimidated and bullied.”
content: SpaceX, the private rocket company, on Thursday fired employees who helped write and distribute an open letter criticizing the behavior of its chief executive, Elon Musk, said three employees with knowledge of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Hari Kumar
title: Torched Trains and Burning Tires: India’s New Military Recruitment Plan Fuels Angry Protests
description: Young people seeking job security in a long-term military career saw the announcement as another blow to their dreams amid rising unemployment.
content: NEW DELHI — Thousands of young Indians took to the streets in angry demonstrations on Friday, blocking trains and setting fire to railroad cars and tires to protest a cost-cutting move by the government that they say will shatter their dreams of a more secure job in the military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Adam Satariano
title: Putin denounces the U.S. as a fading world power.
description: He also mocked what he called the country’s view of itself as “the messenger of the Lord on Earth.”
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday reprised his critique of the United States as a declining power that treats its allies as colonies, while declaring itself exceptional and “the messenger of the Lord on Earth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Through Sweat and Tears, a Cheesemongering Champion Is Crowned
description: At the Cheesemongers Invitational, the competition is fierce, but the feeling of cheese community is strong.
content: Cara Condon was a dark horse heading into the 2022 Cheesemonger Invitational in Brooklyn last Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Vince McMahon Steps Down as Head of W.W.E. During Misconduct Investigation
description: Mr. McMahon, the pro wrestling company’s chairman and chief executive, agreed to pay a secret settlement to an employee with whom he was said to have had an affair, The Wall Street Journal reported this week.
content: Vince McMahon, a longtime executive for World Wrestling Entertainment who led professional wrestling from a sideshow curiosity into a mainstream phenomenon, has stepped down as chairman and chief executive while the company’s board investigates allegations of misconduct against him, the company said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Eurovision rules out Ukraine as host of next year’s song contest.
description: The Eurovision Song Contest’s organizers said on Friday that Russia’s invasion meant Ukraine could not stage next year’s event, even though it won this year’s contest.
content: Kalush Orchestra, a Ukrainian rap act, gave a huge morale boost last month to its war-torn country by cruising to victory at the Eurovision Song Contest — the world’s most watched and glitziest song contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Delves Into Day 3 of the Jan. 6 Hearings
description: Trevor Noah joked that Donald Trump “lives his entire life as if he is the bad kid in one of those antismoking P.S.A.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Reneau, Stella Cooper, Alan Feuer and Aaron Byrd
title: Proud Boys Led Major Breaches of Capitol on Jan. 6, Video Investigation Finds
description: A monthslong Times investigation using court documents, text messages and videos reveals how teams of Proud Boys instigated critical breaches of the Capitol on Jan. 6.
content: For almost 18 months, the Proud Boys have been at the center of the criminal and congressional investigations of the violent attack on the Capitol last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Joel Whitburn, Tireless Researcher of Music Charts, Dies at 82
description: His numerous books delved deeply into the Billboard charts, developing what an admirer called “the de facto history of recorded music.”
content: Joel Whitburn, who relentlessly mined Billboard’s music charts to fill reference books that tell the statistical stories of pop, rock, country, R&B, hip-hop and dance hits since 1940, died on Tuesday at his home in Menomonee Falls, Wis. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What’s the Perfect Summer Dress?
description: A reader asks for help finding a frock that’s suited to warm weather.
content: Ever since Irwin Shaw crafted his bittersweet story, “The Girls in Their Summer Dresses,” and Bruce Springsteen gave the idea his own spin in “Girls in Their Summer Clothes,” the idea of a perfect hot weather garment has hung tantalizingly in our imaginary closet, along with the perfect white shirt, the perfect white tee, the perfect pair of jeans. We chase it in shops everywhere, convinced that if we could find it, at least one of our dressing issues would be solved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The surprising story of ‘warming stripes’
description: One of the most popular ways to visualize rising temperatures is a simple graphic known as warming stripes. Here’s the backstory.
content: June 21 is Show Your Stripes Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Fast-Tracked Bill Stokes Fears of Private Development in 1,200-Acre Park
description: Proponents of a free and open park, who have batted back decades of for-profit proposals for Liberty State Park, worry new legislation could set a dangerous precedent for parks nationwide.
content: With just weeks to go before the state budget deadline, a powerful assortment of New Jersey politicians introduced an expansive new bill tied to an explosive old controversy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: In ‘First Kill,’ Hunter and Prey Fall in Love
description: This Netflix series about a star-crossed teenage romance between a bloodsucker and a monster hunter has roots in both “Romeo and Juliet” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.”
content: When Victoria Schwab sat down to write a short story for an anthology about vampires in 2019, she already knew that she would adapt whatever she wrote for television. So one of the first questions the author, better known by her pen name, V.E. Schwab, asked herself was, what kind of vampire show did she want to watch?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘They Watch Us From the Sky.’
description: Sandy Alcantara and Pablo López of the Miami Marlins have been the N.L.’s best pitchers this season. They are motivated by the loss of a parent and bound by a sense of purpose.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Most baseball players stopped wearing high-cut stirrups years ago, well before Pablo López was born to Danny López and Agnedis Serra in Venezuela in 1996. López, one of two young aces for the Miami Marlins, likes the throwback style but wears stirrups to remind him of Danny, who died of a heart attack two summers ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Need to Find a Bathroom in New York City? Try TikTok.
description: Frustrated by the feat of locating a free restroom in New York City, residents and visitors are compiling and sharing tips.
content: It is a plight familiar to New York City’s nearly nine million residents, and to the millions of tourists who visit each year: nowhere to go to the restroom in a city where public facilities are few and hard to find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: New York Philharmonic Chooses Arts Veteran as Leader
description: Gary Ginstling, executive director of the National Symphony Orchestra, will replace Deborah Borda as the orchestra’s president and chief executive next year.
content: Come this fall, the New York Philharmonic will have a transformed home, when David Geffen Hall reopens after a $550 million renovation. In the not-so-distant future, the orchestra will also get a new music director to replace its departing conductor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Rafael Nadal, Chasing Grand Slam, Will Head to Wimbledon
description: Nadal, hobbled by a foot injury while winning the French Open, said he would play in the grass-court tournament, which begins on June 27.
content: PARIS — The Grand Slam is still in play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Willing to Run Errands in Pursuit of Romance
description: When Dean Dafis got up the courage to ask George Forbes out after their workout class, Mr. Forbes declined, saying he had errands to run. Mr. Dafis didn’t want to take no for an answer.
content: By the time that Konstantinos Dean Dafis introduced himself to George Symmonds Forbes in November 2010, it seemed to Mr. Dafis like he was running into Mr. Forbes almost every weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: Cooper Raiff, Arriving Early to the Party
description: At 25, the indie writer, director and actor is making waves in Hollywood. His second feature, “Cha Cha Real Smooth,” could start a new career chapter.
content: LOS ANGELES — For a while, working behind the camera didn’t appeal much to Cooper Raiff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: The U.S. announces a 3-year agriculture partnership with Ukraine to address the food crisis.
description: The U.S. secretary of agriculture on Thursday announced at the United Nations a three-year agriculture partnership between the United States and Ukraine to address global food insecurity, which has been exacerbated by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: The U.S. secretary of agriculture on Thursday announced at the United Nations a three-year agriculture partnership between the United States and Ukraine to address global food insecurity, which has been exacerbated by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seo
title: Stress Might Age the Immune System, New Study Finds
description: Here’s what the results may mean for you.
content: By now, most people know that stress can take a serious toll on mental and physical health. And when that stress is prolonged, studies suggest, it can increase the risk of certain health conditions like asthma, ulcers, heart attack and stroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Egypt, America’s Middle Eastern ally, maintains warm relations with Putin.
description: The St. Petersburg International Economic Forum being held in Russia on Friday will feature a speech from a surprising world leader: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, a longtime U.S. ally that has for decades been the second-largest recipient of American aid in the world.
content: The St. Petersburg International Economic Forum being held in Russia on Friday will feature a speech from a surprising world leader: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, a longtime U.S. ally that has for decades been the second-largest recipient of American aid in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Non-Monogamy Advocates Ask Facebook to Be More Open
description: A group supporting those who practice polyamory and other forms of “ethical non-monogamy” want more relationship-status options on Facebook.
content: A group that supports ethical non-monogamy sent an open letter to Meta on Thursday calling for Facebook to allow users to list more than one relationship status in their profiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Internal challenges like corruption pose challenges in Ukraine’s bid to join the E.U.
description: The rules for joining the European Union require candidate nations crack down on corruption, a problem that Ukraine has struggled to address, including since President Volodymyr Zelensky took office.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — A majority of Ukrainians and the country’s political elite have for years favored joining the European Union and yet the country has stumbled on most major governance overhauls needed to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: How the Blue Jays’ Manager, Charlie Montoyo, Unwinds
description: Growing up in Puerto Rico, Montoyo learned to play percussion and salsa music.
content: The Major League Baseball season is a grind. First, there’s spring training, which is normally six weeks long. Then, there’s the regular season of 162 games over six months. And, if a team is so lucky, a run to the World Series takes up all of October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Bryce Dallas Howard’s Slow Escape in ‘Jurassic World Dominion’
description: The director Colin Trevorrow narrates a sequence featuring the actor, a testy Therizinosaurus and a murky pond.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: How Louis Theroux Became a ‘Jiggle Jiggle’ Sensation at Age 52
description: Decades into his career, the British American journalist has an unlikely TikTok hit that could be the song of the summer. “I am not trying to make it as a rapper,” he says.
content: Four or five times a week these days, some old friend will contact Louis Theroux and tell him, “My daughter keeps going around the house singing your rap,” or, “My wife was exercising to your rap in her Pilates class.” Passing by a primary school, Mr. Theroux has the feeling he is being watched, a sense confirmed when he hears a kid call out behind him: “My money don’t jiggle jiggle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: Dana Spiotta and Juan Gonzalez
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: WAYWARD, by Dana Spiotta. (Vintage, 336 pp., $17.) Spiotta’s fifth novel, about female aging in contemporary America, follows a woman who reckons with the trappings of wealth and comfort after spontaneously buying a home in Syracuse and divorcing her husband. Our reviewer, Joanna Rakoff, called the book a “virtuosic, singular and very funny portrait of a woman seeking sanity and purpose in a world gone mad.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Spread Some Dirt
description: Pao Roy returns with a wonderfully lively themeless crossword puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Pao Roy, who uses they/them pronouns, they were getting down, so to speak, by making arrows out of the letters I and V. This is Mx. Roy’s third crossword puzzle in The New York Times and their first themeless. In short order, Mx. Roy has become a constructor whose byline I look forward to seeing because it’s obvious how much they care about what they create.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Ready Player Two (or Three)
description: “You can learn a lot from video games: hand-eye coordination and being able to lose.” Fathers talk gaming with their children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Walking on Hot Coals: A Company Event Goes Wrong
description: More than two dozen employees of a Swiss company were injured while walking in bare feet over hot coals, an ancient religious tradition that has become popular on corporate retreats.
content: Walking barefoot across hot coals, an ancient religious ritual popularized in recent years as a corporate team-building exercise, has once again bonded a group of co-workers through the shared suffering of burned feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drake Releases ‘Honestly, Nevermind,’ an LP Dedicated to Virgil Abloh
description: The rapper’s 14-track seventh studio album came out at midnight, about six hours after it was announced on social media.
content: For his last album, Drake kept his fans in anticipation for nearly a year. For his newest one, the wait was about six hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: San Antonio Symphony to Dissolve Amid Labor Dispute
description: The decision will make San Antonio the largest American city without a major orchestra.
content: For almost nine months, the musicians of the San Antonio Symphony were on strike, resisting steep cuts proposed by management that they said would destroy the ensemble. As the dispute dragged on, much of the 2021-22 season was canceled, the players found part-time jobs and mediators tried to negotiate a compromise to save the 83-year-old orchestra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Stock Market Is Plummeting. Welcome to the End of the ‘Everything Bubble.’
description: The financial journalist Rana Foroohar shares her long view on what’s going on with the economy.
content: This week, the S&P 500 entered what analysts refer to as a bear market. The index has plunged around 22 percent from its most recent peak in January. Many growth stocks and crypto assets have crashed double or triple that amount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Michigan’s Chaotic G.O.P. Primary for Governor: ‘It’s a Circus’
description: Taking back the governor’s office in Michigan would be a huge prize for Republicans — but first, they have to get through a messy primary race.
content: The two front-runners are off the ballot, with one moving to a write-in campaign. The next-best known candidate is in court over charges related to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol. And there’s been no shortage of lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Eisenschmidt
description: Take on Friedrich Eisenschmidt in a recreation of a tournament game in Tartu (then known as Dorpat), 1862. Solve for the best series of moves.
content: About Daniel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: European leaders visit Kyiv.
content: The leaders of France, Italy, Germany and Romania met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday in Kyiv, where they pledged support for putting Ukraine on a path to membership in the E.U. and said they would continue to back Ukraine’s military efforts, despite suggestions to the contrary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: My Dad Wasn’t Around, but I Had No Shortage of Black Father Figures
description: For me, fatherly affection came from coaches and the men in my Black Baptist church.
content: I knew about Father’s Day, but I did not celebrate it as a child. It was someone else’s holiday, much like St. Patrick’s Day, which belonged to the Irish and had no hold on me. In grade school I endured the pinch that went along with failure to wear green. Similarly, since I grew up without a father around, the annual June celebration passed without comment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Golden State Beats Boston Celtics to Win N.B.A. Championship
description: It’s the fourth championship in eight seasons for Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Draymond Green.
content: BOSTON — It turns out the dynasty had just been paused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Meet the Peecyclers. Their Idea to Help Farmers Is No. 1.
description: A shortage of chemical fertilizer, worsened by the war in Ukraine, has growers desperate. It just so happens that human urine has the very nutrients that crops need.
content: BRATTLEBORO, Vt. — When Kate Lucy saw a poster in town inviting people to learn about something known as peecycling, she was mystified. “Why would someone pee in a jug and save it?” she wondered. “It sounds like such a wacky idea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Adorante
title: A Teenage Chef Who Brings Soul to California Cuisine
description: Rahanna Bisseret Martinez was a finalist on “Top Chef Junior” and has her own cookbook.
content: Name: Rahanna Bisseret Martinez
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Sometimes ‘Proper’ Speech Isn’t Correct Speech
description: Contractions can be frowned upon. We’re gonna wanna rethink that.
content: My eldest daughter is in elementary school, and I recently started noticing that she was regularly enunciating “going to” and “want to,” no longer saying “gonna” or “wanna,” as many people do in casual speech. I’d say that most of us, on the fly, are more likely to ask, “What time is it gonna be?” than “What time is it going to be?” So, I decided to gently ask her about this, and she said her teachers had told her that “gonna” and “wanna” are not in the dictionary and one should instead say “going to” and “want to.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Wasn’t Bitcoin Supposed to Be a Hedge Against Inflation?
description: Another crypto myth bites the dust.
content: There’s a financial joke, whose origin I don’t know, that has been making the rounds lately. It goes like this: If inflation continues at current rates, the purchasing power of wealth held in dollars will be cut in half over the next eight years. But cryptocurrencies can beat that: They can lose half their value in just a few months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Eat This Outside
description: After a hot day, Hetty McKinnon’s crisp gnocchi with tomato and red onion is a small piece of summer heaven.
content: People often assume, because of my work (and the patriarchy), that I’m the principal cook in my home. It’s true that I am, because I like to do it and I don’t like to clean, which my husband, Blake, is fine with doing. The division of labor is tidy and true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Is Avalanche Defenseman Cale Makar the Stephen Curry of Hockey?
description: “You think you’ve got him, but you don’t,” Lightning defenseman Mikhail Sergachev said. “He just uses you as bait and as a screen. He’s very, very dangerous.”
content: DENVER — The name floats in the ether, now, alongside Cale Makar’s, put there by Wayne Gretzky. On TNT’s hockey program, Gretzky, arguably the best to ever play the game, compared Makar to Bobby Orr, the transcendent defenseman some insist was even better than Gretzky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s streaming picks include an Indonesian buddy film and a thriller about a hit man who doesn’t kill.
content: If you haven’t seen “Filosofi Kopi” or its sequel, no need to fret. “Ben & Jody,” the rollicking third film in the series by the Indonesian director Angga Dwimas Sasongko, offers plenty of pleasures as a stand-alone anticapitalist, pro-environmentalist statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Hochul Spars With Rivals Over Crime, Credentials and Cream Cheese
description: Sharp attacks typified the final debate among Gov. Kathy Hochul and her two Democratic rivals, Jumaane Williams and Representative Tom Suozzi.
content: In the second and final debate in the Democratic primary race for governor of New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul and her two opponents tangled over highly volatile issues, including rising crime, dwindling affordable housing, looming environmental catastrophe — and how they take their bagel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Monika Pronczuk and Dan Bilefsky
title: The European Commission recommends E.U. candidacy for Ukraine and Moldova, but not Georgia.
description: The Commission’s blessing is just the first step on a long road. The final decision will be in the hands of European Union leaders, who will meet June 23 and 24 in Brussels to tackle the thorny question.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s executive branch recommended on Friday that Ukraine be granted candidate status in the country’s bid to become a member, the first formal step in a process that normally lasts longer than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 2: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by June 24 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 6.
content: Welcome to Week Two of our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: N.Y.C.’s vaccine plan for children younger than 5 relies on pediatricians and vaccine hubs.
description: The city hopes to start vaccinating children under 5 on June 22 at many kinds of locations.
content: Health officials in New York City are preparing to distribute vaccines for children younger than 5 starting on June 22, according to a new plan announced on Friday by Mayor Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Arrest of Colorado 14-Year-Old Over a Slap Prompts Excessive-Force Suit
description: The lawsuit claims that a man and his 14-year-old daughter were arrested by officers who used excessive force during the encounter in 2020.
content: The father of a teenage girl filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against three police officers in Loveland, Colo., who arrested her in 2020, saying the men used excessive force when they slammed the 14-year-old onto concrete, fired a Taser at him and choked the family’s Jack Russell terrier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish, Katie Glueck and Michael C. Bender
title: Gun Control Advocates Have More Money Now, but Money Can’t Buy Zeal
description: After more mass shootings, one side is gaining donors and political will; the other is galvanized by gun rights. Will anything be different?
content: After the massacre of schoolchildren at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Conn., in 2012, the gun-control movement was small and badly outspent by the National Rifle Association. Parents seeking an outlet for their grief and rage congregated on Facebook, where they formed their own group, Moms Demand Action, to push for stricter gun laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Luke Broadwater
title: ‘He Took Jan. 6 Personally’
description: Representative Bennie G. Thompson, chairman of the committee investigating the attack on the Capitol, has spent his career fighting to protect the right to vote.
content: BOLTON, Miss.— It was here, in this majority-Black town of 441 people, that Representative Bennie G. Thompson attended a segregated junior high school. It was where his father spent a lifetime working as a mechanic and paying taxes, but never enjoying the right to vote. And it was where the future congressman, in the early 1970s, campaigned for mayor while packing a gun, after receiving threats from white people loath to give up their political power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Tracking Fear on Wall Street
description: Plus, with Revlon’s bankruptcy, Wall Street bankers get ready for a wave of distressed situations.
content: The U.S. stock market, as measured by the S&P 500, tumbled more than 3 percent yesterday, dragging it deeper into bear market territory. This morning, futures markets suggest there will be a rebound, but the S&P is still well on track to record its 10th weekly decline of the past 11 weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel, Eduardo Medina and Johnny Diaz
title: Shooting at Alabama Church Potluck Leaves Three Dead
description: The gunfire ended after a parishioner subdued a man who opened fire inside an Episcopal church, the police said. Capital murder warrants were issued on Friday for the man, Robert Findlay Smith.
content: What started out as a relaxing potluck dinner at an Episcopal church in Alabama on Thursday evening took a sudden and deadly turn when a man pulled out a handgun and opened fire, killing three people, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Really Radical Fashion Idea
description: When is a cruise show not just a cruise show? Ask Maria Grazia Chiuri of Dior.
content: I am beginning to think that Maria Grazia Chiuri, the artistic director of Dior women’s wear, may be the most subversively political, even radical, designer in charge of a big French fashion brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic, Jason Karaian and Isabella Simonetti
title: An ugly week for stocks leaves the S&P 500 with its biggest loss since March 2020.
description: The selling was fueled by persistently high inflation and fears that the Fed’s efforts to tame it with higher interest rates will choke growth.
content: A tumultuous week on Wall Street, which began with stocks plunging into a bear market for the second time during the pandemic, ended with a small gain on Friday. That was little comfort after a brutal period for investors, who have seen the value of their portfolios and retirement funds lurch downward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: BTS Ponders Its Future, and South Korea’s Economy Warily Takes Note
description: The band’s label saw its stock price plunge, and the possibility that the K-pop group won’t tour as pandemic restrictions ease threatens to reverberate through South Korea’s economy.
content: The fallout from BTS’s announcement on Tuesday that the K-pop juggernaut will be taking a break as members explore solo careers was immediate and drastic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: After public pressure, Florida allows pediatricians to order vaccines for very young children.
description: Unlike the other 49 states and the District of Columbia, Florida did not allow health care providers to preorder the vaccines ahead of the federal government’s June 14 deadline.
content: Facing withering pressure from medical professionals and the federal government, Florida began to allow pediatricians, children’s hospitals and other physicians on Friday to order coronavirus vaccines for the youngest children, according to state and White House officials. The shift would ensure that families would be able to get the shots at doctors’ offices, though later than in every other state in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Minnie Driver Paddles Out to Sea
description: The English actress began her memoir, “Managing Expectations,” in the early months of the pandemic.
content: Minnie Driver clambered into a pink-and-green kayak, adjusted her legs against the foot pegs, grabbed her paddle and pushed off the wobbling dock into a choppy Hudson River. “See you in Weehawken,” she said, yelling over her shoulder. A Canada goose looked on, mildly impressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Here is what to know about the Covid vaccine for infants and toddlers.
description: Millions of U.S. parents are crossing their fingers again this week that Covid-19 vaccines will soon be available for younger age groups. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend that the agency authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for use in very young children.
content: Millions of U.S. parents are crossing their fingers again this week that Covid-19 vaccines will soon be available for younger age groups. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend that the agency authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for use in very young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: A Day After a Portrait of Pence in Danger, Trump Attacks Him Again
description: In a speech, Donald J. Trump was undeterred by the Jan. 6 House committee’s account of how his rioting supporters menaced the vice president, and the panel’s dismantling of many of his election lies.
content: A day after the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 assault illustrated the serious danger that rioters posed to Mike Pence, former President Donald J. Trump unleashed a new attack on the man who had served him as vice president, criticizing him for refusing to interfere with the Electoral College certification of the 2020 presidential contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Falling for Each Other, Then a First Date
description: Julie Hagenbuch and Eddy López Noguera enjoyed spending time together, but they shied away from anything romantic — until they couldn’t.
content: Though Julie Louisa Hagenbuch and Eddy Arturo López Noguera developed a friendship not long after meeting in September 2016, it would take 11 months for them to consider one of their outings as an actual date. And by that point, both say they had already started to fall in love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Fed’s Newfound Aggressiveness Is Concerning
description: Its fight against inflation could very well cause a recession.
content: When it comes to fighting inflation, Esther George is accustomed to being a hawk among doves. Now, in a strange turnabout, she is a dove among hawks. George, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, was the only member of the Federal Open Market Committee to vote on Wednesday against the Fed’s increase of three-quarters of a percentage point in the key short-term lending rate it controls. She favored a half-percentage-point increase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Stephen Curry Left His Critics With Nothing Else to Say
description: Four N.B.A. championships. Two Most Valuable Player Awards. And yes, a finals M.V.P. Golden State’s Curry has nothing else to prove.
content: BOSTON — A few seconds remained in Stephen Curry’s N.B.A. season when he spotted his father, Dell, sitting along one of the baselines. He went over to embrace him, then fell to the court in tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks Executive, Prominent in Push Against Union Drive, Will Leave
description: Rossann Williams, president of retail for North America, will depart after 17 years at the company, which said she declined a new position with Starbucks.
content: Starbucks said Friday that an executive who played a key role in the company’s response to a growing union campaign would leave by the end of the month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Return to Office Revolt
description: More and more office workers are being called back to their cubicles. Many are not having it.
content: After more than two years of remote work, more and more office workers are being called back to their cubicles. Many are not having it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Gottlieb
title: Love Your Dog, but Beware of Your Homeowners’ Insurance
description: Many firms have long refused coverage or charge more for pit bulls and other dogs considered more dangerous, but New York and other states say policies shouldn’t be breed specific.
content: When Brian English applied for renters’ insurance a few years ago, he described his dogs, Venom and Jean, as “mixed breed.” — a category that certainly covers pit bulls. Another time on an application, he wrote, “American Staffordshire terrier,” a fancier-sounding name for a type of pit bull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Christina Anderson
title: A High-Flying Italian Surgeon’s Fall From Grace
description: Dr. Paolo Macchiarini became a star by creating a “bioartificial” windpipe. But it did not work, and a court in Sweden has found him criminally liable for the harm inflicted on a patient.
content: LONDON — It sounded like real-life science fiction — a 3-D printed organ, a groundbreaking artificial windpipe, built in a laboratory and made to order. The charismatic Italian surgeon who designed it foresaw a future where hearts and lungs could be made from plastic, and organ donations became a thing of the past. Almost overnight, he became a superstar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Bartees Strange Ponders Success in Dire Times
description: On his second album, “Farm to Table,” the indie-rock singer and songwriter finds no easy comforts in his own ascent.
content: By chance, choice and artistic inclination, Bartees Strange has been a lifelong outlier — a position his songs grapple with, exult in and constantly question on his second studio album, “Farm to Table.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Future Isn’t Female Anymore
description: Where is the women’s movement when we need it most?
content: The Drift, a buzzy literary journal founded by Kiara Barrow and Rebecca Panovka, left-leaning women in their late 20s, published a series of short essays earlier this year under the rubric, “What to Do About Feminism.” “For a long time now, we’ve had the sense that feminism is in trouble,” Barrow and Panovka wrote in the introduction. They described an ambient feeling that feminism has been sapped of cultural vitality, even as an anti-feminist backlash is gathering momentum, and that young people especially were turning against the movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: Clint Bowyer, Former NASCAR Driver, Involved in Fatal Car Accident
description: Mr. Bowyer, now a Fox Sports analyst, called 911 and showed no sign of impairment after striking a woman with his car on a Missouri highway on June 5, the authorities said.
content: Clint Bowyer, a Fox Sports analyst and former NASCAR Cup Series driver, was involved in a car accident in Missouri last week in which he struck and killed a woman who was walking on a highway, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Getting Back to Peace Talks
description: We talk to our chief diplomatic correspondent in Europe about the prospects.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: High on Helping: The Dangers of Voluntourism
description: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Ketong Li, age 17.
content: This essay, by Ketong Li, age 17, from Miss Porter’s School in Farmington, Conn., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: The Biggest Surprises of the Jan. 6 Hearings So Far
description: Maggie Haberman breaks down the House select committee’s first two weeks of public testimony.
content: After interviewing more than 1,000 witnesses and assembling a trove of well over 140,000 documents, the House committee investigating the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021, is finally unveiling its findings to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: The Coin That Could Wreck Crypto
description: As cryptocurrencies have plunged, attention has focused on a potential point of vulnerability: the market’s reliance on a so-called stablecoin called Tether.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Cryptocurrency prices are plummeting. A so-called stablecoin lost all its value in a matter of days. A newfangled crypto bank halted withdrawals. And investors have been plunged into financial ruin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Reflecting on a Deep Investigation
description: Azmat Khan, the journalist behind a Times series that revealed how U.S. air wars were resulting in a staggering number of civilian casualties, shares how the investigation changed how she thinks about reporting.
content: In early 2016, Azmat Khan, a journalist for The New York Times Magazine, began an investigation that lasted more than five years and was part of a group of Times articles that won the Pulitzer Prize this year for international reporting. In the series, Ms. Khan uncovered systemic flaws behind the air wars conducted by the United States in Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria and the lack of transparency surrounding more than 1,300 reports of civilian casualties. In a recent interview, Ms. Khan reflected on the reporting challenges and what the experience taught her. This interview has been edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tatiana Jackson-Saitz
title: A Texting Lifeline During a Difficult Time
description: As her father struggled with cancer, a flirtation provided distraction — and then something more.
content: I chose my college based on the vibes of the people in the school’s accepted students Facebook group. This one blond boy commented on my introduction post saying he also liked a favorite artist of mine, and my friend told me that was proof enough — if there’s one, there’s bound to be more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: What to Know About the Covid Vaccine for Little Kids
description: Here are answers to five common questions.
content: Millions of U.S. parents — including many of my friends with children under 5 — are crossing their fingers again this week that Covid-19 vaccines will soon be available for younger age groups. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend that the agency authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for use in very young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: The Met Opera Orchestra Raises a Glorious Noise
description: The orchestra’s power in theatrical music was on display in two concerts at Carnegie Hall led by Yannick Nézet-Séguin.
content: Over two nights at Carnegie Hall, Yannick Nézet-Séguin led the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in an awesome display of its might. After an eventful season, in which concerns beyond music sometimes pulled attention from the stage, these back-to-back concerts were a reminder of the orchestra’s pre-eminence in theatrical material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Takashi Murakami
title: Repainting the Canvas, One Pixel at a Time
description: Amid bytes and blockchains, artists are exploring worlds buoyed by technology and fueled by imagination.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: Erin Doherty Shape Shifts in ‘Chloe’
description: The actress, known for playing Princess Anne in “The Crown,” embodies a working class con woman in a new limited series on Amazon Prime Video.
content: LONDON — After playing Princess Anne in two seasons of “The Crown,” Erin Doherty realized that people assumed she had a similar — if not quite as regal — background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Grace Ashford
title: 5 Takeaways From the Last Democratic Debate for New York Governor
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul touted her record and beat back criticism from her rivals during their second and final debate ahead of the June 28 primary.
content: The stakes in Thursday’s Democratic debate for governor of New York State were relatively low for Gov. Kathy Hochul, the race’s front-runner. She had to withstand an onslaught of attacks from her rival candidates, while making no major errors. She appeared to achieve those modest aims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: She Won a Tony. But Deirdre O’Connell ‘Can’t Think About That.’
description: We spoke to the veteran actress as she returned to work, preparing for the opening of her new Off Broadway show “Corsicana.”
content: When Deirdre O’Connell returned to work two days after winning this year’s Tony Award for best performance by a leading actress in a play, the production staff of her current show, “Corsicana” at Playwrights Horizons, greeted her with a balloon arch and cake. O’Connell, 68, enjoyed it. For a little while, anyway. But “Corsicana,” a lonesome, oblique quartet by Will Arbery, is in previews. It begins press performances soon. O’Connell needed to rehearse. So she put the celebration aside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Standiford
title: Young, Gifted and Searching for a Sense of Self
description: A quiz bowl winner and students at an elite music camp struggle to figure out who they really are in novels by Kate Egan and Mariama J. Lockington.
content: GOLDEN TICKET, by Kate EganIN THE KEY OF US, by Mariama J. Lockington
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Stephanie Lai
title: Gun Talks Snag on Tricky Question: What Counts as a Boyfriend?
description: Among the sticking points holding up a final agreement on gun legislation is how to define a boyfriend in a provision meant to keep guns away from domestic abusers.
content: WASHINGTON — Among the sticking points standing in the way of a final deal on what could be the first significant bipartisan gun safety legislation in decades is an age-old question: How do you define a boyfriend?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dickinson
title: Colombia Is Slipping Back Toward Violence. The Next President Can Stop That.
description: Neither candidate has a clear plan to contain rising levels of conflict and armed violence in the countryside.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Last month a criminal armed group shut down much of the northern third of Colombia — largely uncontested. “We decree four days of Armed Strike from this moment,” read the May 5 pamphlet ordering the population to stay indoors, the shops to close and the roads to be empty. The Gulf Clan, a paramilitary-style drug trafficking group, initiated the strike against the Colombian government in retaliation for the capture and extradition of its leader, Dairo Antonio Úsuga, known as Otoniel, to the United States. “We are not responsible for what happens to those who do not comply,” the group warned ominously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Mariupol, a symbol of the war’s human cost, likely was Ukraine’s ‘deadliest place’ through April.
description: The southern port of Mariupol has become a potent emblem of the human toll of the war in Ukraine, a besieged city where trapped residents went for weeks without electricity or water, and where people dug trenches to accommodate the mounting numbers of bodies.
content: The southern port of Mariupol has become a potent emblem of the human toll of the war in Ukraine, a besieged city where trapped residents went for weeks without electricity or water, and where people dug trenches to accommodate the mounting numbers of bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Your Backyard Is Actually a Lucrative Private Dog Park — if You Say It Is
description: A new generation of apps is allowing homeowners to make extra money by renting out their pools, yards and living rooms for an hour at a time.
content: Greg Jessup likes to squeeze money out of his five-bedroom house in Wilton, Conn., wherever possible, frequently listing it on Airbnb. But this spring, he took a good look at the space around the house and saw its potential, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Colombia Will Soon Have Its First Black Female Vice President. Will It Be Her?
description: A few months ago, Marelen Castillo was a top director of a Catholic university. Now, she is one of two Afro-Colombian women who could become the country’s next second in command.
content: CALI, Colombia — At a hotel in Cali, a major city near Colombia’s Pacific Coast, hundreds of people packed a ballroom for the woman at the center of the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Celebrity Divorce Lawyer Spends Her Sundays
description: Nancy Chemtob is committed to meditation and self-help books, as well as her clients, family members and new husband.
content: Nancy Chemtob, a matrimonial lawyer, has helped Mary-Kate Olsen, Tory Burch, Bobby Flay and other celebrities get divorced. After practicing for decades as the founding partner of Chemtob Moss Forman & Beyda, one of the largest matrimonial firms in New York City, Ms. Chemtob went through a divorce herself, in 2012.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Catching His Eye on the (Ecstatic) Dance Floor
description: After several dates, Sanjay Amin drove 15 hours to quarantine with Rachael Cruthirds in Portland, Ore. They have barely been apart since.
content: When Sanjay Aakash Amin told his therapist that, one year after breaking off an engagement, he still had reservations about meeting people in bars or on apps, she suggested he attend an ecstatic dance party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greek Court Rejects Effort to Toughen Punishment After Killing of an American
description: Bakari Henderson, a college graduate from Texas, was beaten to death in a resort area in July 2017. The court on Friday upheld the original convictions.
content: ATHENS — A Greek court on Friday rejected an effort to toughen the punishment for a group of men convicted in the beating death of an American on a holiday island in 2017, upholding the original convictions of six men for grievous assault and spurning a call to find them guilty of murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: The Good, the Bad and the Cringe of the Juneteenth Gold Rush
description: Juneteenth was made a federal holiday in 2021, but this year big-box stores like Walmart have been going all out with themed party supplies, sometimes crowding out smaller vendors.
content: Brandy Goodner first learned about Juneteenth when she was 14. Although she didn’t begin celebrating the holiday — a commemoration of the day in 1865 that enslaved people in Texas were told that they had been freed two years earlier — until she was an adult, Ms. Goodner now parties like she’s making up for lost time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: This Is Going to Hurt
description: Inflation is expected to remain high later this year even as the economy slows and layoffs rise. Already, signs of financial stress are surfacing.
content: Kat Johnston didn’t expect the pandemic to make her less stressed about her finances. After all, she temporarily lost her job at the library where she worked full time. But, like many Americans, she found an unexpected reprieve from money worries: Months at home limited her spending, and she received expanded unemployment insurance and two one-time checks from the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: How Can You Travel for Less Than $100 a Day, Everything Included? Find a Cruise Deal.
description: As companies bring their full fleets back online, many ships still have room. That means bargains are being offered outside the winter “wave season,” making some sailings unexpectedly cheap, even in an era of inflation.
content: A $50-a-day offer to sail on a Caribbean cruise ship with pools, water slides, restaurants and Broadway-style entertainment says a lot about the turbulence some cruise companies are facing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: George Lamming, Who Chronicled the End of Colonialism, Dies at 94
description: Born in Barbados, he was among the last of a generation of writers who traced the Caribbean’s transition to independence.
content: George Lamming, a novelist and essayist from Barbados who was among the last of a generation of Caribbean writers whose work traced their region’s transition from colonialism to independence, died on June 4 at his home in Bridgetown, his country’s capital. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Police Error Led to Trump-Era Subpoena to Twitter About a Devin Nunes Critic
description: Newly disclosed files show a Capitol Police analyst misidentified which Twitter account had posted a threatening message about Mitch McConnell.
content: WASHINGTON — Newly disclosed documents have cleared up a mystery that arose in May 2021, after it came to light that the Justice Department under President Donald J. Trump had secretly obtained a grand jury subpoena seeking to unmask the person behind a Twitter account dedicated to mocking a political ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monica Khemsurov
title: 13 Standouts From Salone Del Mobile
description: This month’s iteration of the Milan furniture fair brought straw baskets, paper lanterns, color-blocked carpets and more.
content: Because of Covid-19 and unrelenting global supply chain issues, the annual Salone del Mobile furniture fair in Milan moved from April to June this year, and thus celebrated its 60th anniversary last week, a bit behind schedule. Typically the international design scene’s harbinger of spring, this latest edition, which T kicked off with a rollicking garden party at Villa Necchi Campiglio, turned into something of a sticky endurance test, one with 85-degree temperatures, sudden rainstorms and nary an air-conditioned room in sight. Yet more than a quarter-million attendees decided to brave the elements for the sheer creativity on display, from recent graduates’ wild experiments with material to anticipated new releases from established names. Here are 13 of the most inspiring things we saw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Overlooked No More: William B. Gould, Escaped Slave and Civil War Diarist
description: He served nearly three years in the U.S. Navy and documented almost all of it, leaving an invaluable record of Black life during the war.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Andy Newman and Ana Ley
title: New York City Estimates More Unsheltered People, but Comparisons Are Tricky
description: The significance of the new numbers can be hard to discern, because city officials used different methods to tally a subpopulation during the pandemic.
content: The population of New Yorkers living in streets and subways decreased slightly from the last prepandemic survey in 2020, according to a new city survey, but advocates for homeless people say the numbers are unreliable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rikki Novetsky, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Clare Toeniskoetter, Will Reid, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Brad Fisher, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: What the Jan. 6 Hearings Have Revealed So Far
description: The House committee investigating the Capitol riot is laying out the extent of former President Donald Trump’s attempts to remain in power after the 2020 election.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: A Case for Frozen Mixed Vegetables
description: The medley of corn, carrots and peas is more than just a convenient freezer staple. It’s an essential piece of American culinary history.
content: When the Australian pop star Troye Sivan sings the line, “Take a trip into my garden, I’ve got so much to show ya” in his 2018 summer bop “Bloom,” he probably isn’t referring to an icy Eden of corn, carrots and peas. But he should be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: How a Globetrotting Family Learned to Love Soccer and the ‘Grey Wiggle’
description: Over many years and locations, we had come to almost worship the World Cup, something that let us bond with almost anyone, anywhere.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — I woke up early Tuesday morning, figuring that the World Cup qualifier in Qatar between Australia and Peru would already be over — but no. It was still scoreless after extra time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Drake Looks for Love, Repeatedly, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by beabadoobee, Perfume Genius, the Beths and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Furman and Michelle Groskopf
title: Not Your Average Pride Event
description: Dyke Day LA takes a homespun approach to a month typically packed with corporate-sponsored parties, parades and concerts.
content: Last weekend, droves of people descended on a 15-acre park in northeast Los Angeles for an afternoon of picnicking, mingling, cheering on drag performances and a puppy costume competition, and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: The Watergate Hearings, 50 Years Ago: Truth Was Not Up for Debate
description: On the anniversary of the June 17, 1972, break-in, alumni of the hearings gather for a reunion. They had it easier than the Jan. 6 committee, they say.
content: WASHINGTON — In the grandly marbled space of the Russell Senate Office Building known as the Kennedy Caucus Room, where a bipartisan select committee held nationally televised hearings to investigate the burglary of the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate a half-century ago, alumni of that inquiry gathered Friday evening to reminisce — and issue warnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Remains of British Journalist Dom Phillips Identified, Brazilian Police Say
description: The remains of a second person, believed to be Bruno Pereira, who disappeared with Mr. Phillips in the Amazon on June 5, were still being analyzed.
content: SÃO PAULO — A forensic exam carried out on human remains found in the Amazon rainforest confirmed on Friday that they belonged to the British journalist Dom Phillips, Brazil’s federal police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
title: Fuel-Starved and Stuck in Crisis, Sri Lanka Orders Work from Home
description: The decree applies to employees of the state and education sectors, and was aimed at reducing the rush to public transport in the nation of 21 million.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Out of fuel and struggling to contain a deepening economic crisis, Sri Lanka on Friday ordered government employees to work from home to reduce the rush on public transport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Tim Sale, Comic Book Artist Who Reimagined Batman, Dies at 66
description: Series like “Batman: The Long Halloween” influenced big-screen images of the hero, while “Superman for All Seasons” was another fan favorite.
content: Tim Sale, an award-winning comic book artist best known for his work on the DC Comics characters Batman and Superman and for influencing depictions of the Caped Crusader in numerous films, died on Thursday in Seattle. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Covid Vaccine and Fisheries Deals Close a ‘Roller Coaster’ W.T.O. Meeting
description: Members of the global trade group were forced to scale back plans for more ambitious agreements, but they were ultimately able to reach several deals at a meeting in Geneva.
content: WASHINGTON — Members of the World Trade Organization announced several agreements on Friday at the close of their first in-person ministerial conference in four years, pledging to rein in harmful government policies that have encouraged overfishing and relax some controls on intellectual property in an effort to make coronavirus vaccines more widely available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Torn Between Grief and the Future
description: “I needed my grief, but I also couldn’t stand it.”
content: In this week’s Modern Love essay, “A Texting Lifeline During a Difficult Time,” Tatiana Jackson-Saitz writes about the complexities of falling in love while losing her father to cancer.
